Hello fellow Gatsby-er! Welcome to part one of our community Gatsby.js tutorial.

Whatâ€™s in this tutorial?

In this tutorial youâ€™ll be gently introduced to the Gatsby development environment, how to create component pages, and how to build and deploy Gatsby sites.

Sit down, buckle up, and letâ€™s get going!

Check your development environment

Letâ€™s check first that you have everything set up to start creating with Gatsby. You will need a recent version of Node.js installed.

Node.js is a programming tool for running JavaScript on servers and in your computerâ€™s terminal. Gatsby is built using Node.js.

Open a terminal window. See terminal instructions for Mac users and terminal instructions for Windows users. In your terminal window, type node --version and hit ENTER, then npm --version and hit ENTER (tip: to run a specified command, you must type the command into your terminal and then press ENTER. Then the command will run).

You should see something like:

Gatsby supports versions of Node back to v6 and npm to v3.

If you donâ€™t have Node.js installed, go to https://nodejs.org/ and install the recommended version for your operating system.

Install the â€œHello Worldâ€ starter

Gatsby uses â€œstartersâ€ for starting new projects. Starters are partially built Gatsby sites that are pre-configured to help you get moving faster. There are several official starters and many others contributed from the Gatsby community! See the Starters page for the full list.

To install a starter, first install Gatsbyâ€™s command line program by running the following:

npm install --global gatsby-cli

Once thatâ€™s installed, open a new terminal window and run the following commands to create a new Gatsby site in a directory called tutorial-part-one and then move to this new directory:

gatsby new tutorial-part-one https://github.com/gatsbyjs/gatsby-starter-hello-world#v2
cd tutorial-part-one

This command downloads the files for the starter and then installs the needed npm packages. It should take around 1.5-3 minutes to finish. It may look like nothing is happening at first; be patient!

Now letâ€™s try running Gatsby!

Gatsby has a built-in development server. Letâ€™s start it up by running the following command:

gatsby develop

You should shortly see some text, close to the bottom, that says:

You can now view gatsby-starter-hello-world in the browser.

http://localhost:8000/.

Open that address in your browser andâ€¦

Yeah! Itâ€™s working!!!

Too cool ğŸ˜

Gatsbyâ€™s development server is a â€œhot reloadingâ€ server, meaning any change you make to your React.js page components (and later youâ€™ll learn, your data files) will be immediately visible and/or loaded in the browser.

This is huge because it makes development so much faster and fun.

Letâ€™s try it.

Youâ€™ll need code editing software for the next part of this tutorial. VS Code is a nice one. With your code editor, open the folder on your computer called â€œtutorial-part-one,â€ which was automatically created in the location you chose when you ran the gatsby new terminal command above.

Once youâ€™ve opened the â€œtutorial-part-oneâ€ folder in your code editing software, itâ€™s time to edit your website. Youâ€™ll see groups of directories and files; find the file in this location: src/pages/index.js. Once you open that file, try changing â€œHello world!â€ in the page component to â€œHello Gatsby!â€œ. Once you save that change, the text in your browser should change within a second (tip: you will always need to save changes before they appear in your browser).

Try some other tricks, like the ones below:

  1. Gatsby lets you add â€œinline stylesâ€ via a JavaScript style â€œpropâ€ (youâ€™ll learn about other styling options later).

    Try replacing your page component with this:

import React from "react"

export default () => <div style={{ color: `blue` }}>Hello Gatsby!</div>

Change the color to â€œpinkâ€. Then to â€œtomatoâ€.

  1. Add some paragraph text.
import React from "react"

export default () => (
  <div style={{ color: `tomato` }}>
    <h1>Hello Gatsby!</h1>
    <p>What a world.</p>
  </div>
)
  1. Add an image (in this case, a random one from Unsplash)
import React from "react"

export default () => (
  <div style={{ color: `tomato` }}>
    <h1>Hello Gatsby!</h1>
    <p>What a world.</p>
    <img src="https://source.unsplash.com/random/400x200" alt="" />
  </div>
)

Now your screen should look something like this:

Linking between pages

Websites are pages and links between pages. While youâ€™ve now got a pretty sweet first pageâ€”one page and no links doesnâ€™t feel very webby. So letâ€™s create a new page.

First create the link to the new page.

To do that, import the <Link> component from the gatsby package that was installed along with the starter.

Unlike the normal HTML <a> element, Gatsbyâ€™s Link component uses the â€toâ€ prop for specifying the page you want to link to. Letâ€™s link to a page with the pathname of /page-2/. Try adding that. Once youâ€™re done, the page component should look like:

import React from "react"
import { Link } from "gatsby"

export default () => (
  <div style={{ color: `tomato` }}>
    <h1>Hello Gatsby!</h1>
    <p>What a world.</p>
    <img src="https://source.unsplash.com/random/400x200" alt="" />
    <br />
    <div>
      <Link to="/page-2/">Link</Link>
    </div>
  </div>
)

If you click on that link in the browser you should see:

What youâ€™re seeing is the Gatsby.js development 404 page. Letâ€™s do what it says and create a React.js page component at src/pages/page-2.js.

Make the second page component look something like:

import React from "react"
import { Link } from "gatsby"

export default () => (
  <div>
    <p>Hello world from my second Gatsby page</p>
    <Link to="/">back home</Link>
  </div>
)

Save that and now you should be able to click back and forth between the two pages!

Challenge: Using the instructions above as hints, see if you can create a third page and link to it from the home page.

Interactive page

One nice thing about using Gatsby for building websites vs. other tools is that itÊ¼s simple to add interactivity to your pages. Since Gatsby uses React for everything, itâ€™s no extra setup work to go beyond normal content templates to rich client interactivity. React excels at building applications as it was designed for Facebook.com and is used on many other world-class web applications.

Letâ€™s see how to add interactivity to your pages. Letâ€™s start with a counter.

Youâ€™ll start by creating a new link to a page at /counter/ from your original index.js page component <Link to="/counter/">Counter</Link>.

import React from "react"
import { Link } from "gatsby"

export default () => (
  <div style={{ color: `tomato` }}>
    <h1>Hello Gatsby!</h1>
    <p>What a world.</p>
    <img src="https://source.unsplash.com/random/400x200" alt="" />
    <br />
    <div>
      <Link to="/page-2/">Link</Link>
    </div>
    <div>
      <Link to="/counter/">Counter</Link>
    </div>
  </div>
)

Add that link, click on it, and then youâ€™ll create a â€œHello Worldâ€ page component for /counter/ as before. But instead of using the â€œfunctional componentâ€ form as you did before, this time youâ€™ll create a â€œclassâ€ component at src/pages/counter.js.

import React from "react"

class Counter extends React.Component {
  render() {
    return <div>Hello Class Component</div>
  }
}

export default Counter

The class form of React allows you to have component state. Youâ€™ll need that for your counter.

Letâ€™s continue to flesh out your counter. Letâ€™s add two buttons. One to increment and one to decrement the count of the counter.

import React from "react"

class Counter extends React.Component {
  render() {
    return (
      <div>
        <h1>Counter</h1>
        <p>current count: 0</p>
        <button>plus</button>
        <button>minus</button>
      </div>
    )
  }
}

export default Counter

Now you have everything you need to make a nice counter. Letâ€™s make it live.

First youâ€™ll set up the component state.

import React from "react"

class Counter extends React.Component {
  constructor() {
    super()
    this.state = { count: 0 }
  }

  render() {
    return (
      <div>
        <h1>Counter</h1>
        <p>current count: {this.state.count}</p>
        <button>plus</button>
        <button>minus</button>
      </div>
    )
  }
}

export default Counter

Youâ€™re now rendering the current count from the component state.

Letâ€™s now change the state when you click on your buttons.

import React from "react"

class Counter extends React.Component {
  constructor() {
    super()
    this.state = { count: 0 }
  }

  render() {
    return (
      <div>
        <h1>Counter</h1>
        <p>current count: {this.state.count}</p>
        <button
          onClick={() =>
            this.setState(prevState => ({
              count: prevState.count + 1,
            }))
          }
        >
          plus
        </button>
        <button
          onClick={() =>
            this.setState(prevState => ({
              count: prevState.count - 1,
            }))
          }
        >
          minus
        </button>
      </div>
    )
  }
}

export default Counter

There you go! A working React.js counter inside your static website ğŸ‘Œ

Because Gatsby is just React, itâ€™s easy to add web app features to your Gatsby sites as needed e.g. talk to APIs, add logged-in features, etc.

Bonus challenge: One fun thing is that hot reloading isnâ€™t just for content and styles; it works on code as well. Currently, when you click the buttons on the counter, the numbers go up and down in increments of 1. Try to make the counter go up and down in a different increments (for example, 5).

Deploying Gatsby.js websites

Gatsby.js is a static site generator, which means there are no servers to setup or complicated databases to deploy. Instead, the Gatsby build command produces a directory of static HTML and JavaScript files which you can deploy to a static site hosting service.

Letâ€™s try using Surge for deploying your first Gatsby website. Surge is one of many â€œstatic site hostsâ€ which make it possible to deploy Gatsby sites.

If you havenâ€™t previously installed & setup Surge, open a new terminal window and install their terminal tool:

npm install --global surge

# Then create a (free) account with them
surge

Next, build your site by running the following command in the terminal at the root of your site (tip: make sure youâ€™re running this command at the root of your site, in this case in the tutorial-part-one folder, which you can do by opening a new tab in the same window you used to run gatsby develop):

gatsby build

Building should take 15-30 seconds. Once the build is finished, itâ€™s interesting to take a look at the files that the gatsby build command just prepared to deploy. Take a look at a list of the generated files by typing in the following terminal command into the root of your site, which will let you look at the public directory:

ls public

Then finally deploy your site by publishing the generated files to surge.sh.

surge public/

Once this finishes running, you should see in your terminal something like:

Open the web address listed on the bottom line (lowly-pain.surge.sh in this case) and youâ€™ll see your newly published site! Great work!

Whatâ€™s coming next?

In this tutorial, youâ€™ve installed Gatsby, played in the development environment, and deployed your first site! Awesome! We hope youâ€™re enjoying yourself so far. Feel free to continue now to part two of the tutorial, â€œIntroduction to using CSS in Gatsbyâ€, or go exploring around the rest of the site.
